title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Program Overview
The BYU Associate Product Manager (APM) Internships are for-credit, apprenticeship-style internships designed for high-performing undergraduate students majoring in Strategic Management at Brigham Young University.
Students work on real product and product-adjacent initiatives at company partners while earning academic credit toward their degree.
Students in this program typically complete STRAT 490R - Creating Digital Products with AI to build foundational product management and cutting edge AI skills before their internship.

title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Program At a Glance



Duration
4 months


Period
January 7 – April 15, 2026


Hours
10-20 hours per week


Credit
3.0-6.0 credit hours


Location
In-person or remote

title: Schedule

Pre-Internship (Before January 7)
Companies may begin onboarding early:

Initial introductions and meetings

title: Getting Started
text:
Before Your Start Date
Welcome to the BYU Associate Product Manager (APM) Internship Program. This guide will help you hit the ground running.

title: Getting Started
text:
Connect with your assigned mentor/manager
Confirm your work schedule and location (remote or in-person)
Set up any required accounts or access
Review the Program Overview

title: Getting Started
text:
First Week Checklist

Attend onboarding meeting with your mentor
Clarify goals, scope, and priorities for your internship
Understand team communication norms (Slack, email, meetings)
Set up your development environment if applicable
Schedule recurring check-ins (minimum 1x per week recommended)

title: Getting Started
text:
Key Dates



Milestone
Date




Official Start Date
January 7, 2026


End of Internship
April 15, 2026


Weekly Updates Due
By midnight Saturday

title: Getting Started
text:
Your Responsibilities
As an APM intern, you are expected to:

Confirm expectations and ask clarifying questions as needed
Deliver high-quality work and meet deadlines
Come prepared to meetings with updates, questions, and next steps
Engage actively and be open to feedback
Proactively communicate progress, blockers, and availability
Build competence by learning and applying necessary skills
Send end-of-week recap emails to your manager/mentor with strategy-program@byu.edu in CC

title: Getting Started
text:
What You’ll Be Working On
Students support teams in product management, AI product building, and product-adjacent roles, contributing to:

Product discovery and customer research
Feature definition and prioritization
Prototyping and experimentation
Analytics, insights, and execution support

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Deadline
A key part of your internship is sending a concise end-of-week progress email. This keeps your mentor informed and demonstrates professional communication skills.
Saturday by 11:59 PM
The timing of the end-of-week email is intentional. It gives you time to reflect on accomplishments, set priorities for the coming week, flag any blocker or concerns, and ensures you stay in sync with your manager.

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Recipients

To: Your assigned mentor/manager
CC: strategy-program@byu.edu

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Email Format
Your weekly update should include three sections:
1. What I Working on and Accomplished This Week [Required] - List completed tasks and deliverables - Be specific about outcomes, not just activities - Include any metrics or results if applicable
2. Plans for Next Week [Required] - Outline your priorities and planned tasks - Be realistic about what you can accomplish
3. Blockers, Risks, or Dependencies [May exclude if none] - Flag anything that might impact your progress - Include items you need from others - Mention any questions or decisions needed

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Example Email
Subject: Weekly Update - [Your Name] - Week of Jan 13

Hi [Mentor Name],

This week I worked on and accomplished the following:
- Completed user interviews with 5 customers
- Drafted initial feature requirements document
- Set up analytics tracking for onboarding flow

Next week, my priorities are:
- Synthesize interview findings into insights report
- Present recommendations to product team
- Begin wireframing priority features

There are a couple things to flag:
- I am still Waiting on access to customer database (requested Tuesday)
- I have a mid-term on Wednesday and will be unvailable that day for any meeting or work time

See you next week,
[Your Name]

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Tips for Effective Updates

Be concise and use bullet points to structure your email
Lead with outcomes — what got done, not just what you worked on
Be honest about blockers — early communication prevents surprises
Send on time — consistency builds trust

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Product Discovery
This page provides foundational resources for the core skills you’ll develop during your APM internship.
Product discovery is the process of understanding customer needs and validating solutions before building.

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Key Activities

Customer interviews
Problem framing
Opportunity assessment
Solution validation



Resources

Continuous Discovery Habits by Teresa Torres
The Mom Test by Rob Fitzpatrick

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Feature Definition & Prioritization
Turning insights into clear, actionable product requirements.

Key Activities

Writing user stories
Defining acceptance criteria
Prioritization frameworks (RICE, MoSCoW, etc.)
Creating product requirements documents (PRDs)



User Story Format
As a [type of user],
I want [goal/desire],
so that [benefit/value].

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Prototyping & Experimentation
Testing ideas quickly before committing to full development.

Key Activities

Low-fidelity wireframes
Clickable prototypes
A/B testing
MVP definition



Tools to Explore

Figma (design & prototyping)
Miro (whiteboarding)
Notion (documentation)

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Analytics & Insights
Using data to inform product decisions.

Key Activities

Defining success metrics
Analyzing user behavior
Creating dashboards
Presenting findings



Common Metrics

Activation rate
Retention/churn
Feature adoption
Task completion rate

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Communication & Stakeholder Management
Product managers spend significant time communicating across teams.

Key Skills

Running effective meetings
Writing clear documentation
Presenting to stakeholders
Managing competing priorities

title: Grading
text:
Grade Components (290 points possible)
Students receive a letter grade for the credit hours they are earning. Grades are based on weekly update emails, end-of-term mentor feedback, and an optional extra credit survey.

title: Grading
text:
1. Weekly Progress Emails (Student Responsibility)
Your weekly updates demonstrate:

Consistent communication
Professional writing skills
Accountability and follow-through
Proactive identification of blockers

See Weekly Updates for format and expectations.
Deadline: Every Saturday by 11:59 PM


2. End-of-Term Mentor Feedback (Employer Responsibility)
At the conclusion of the internship (April 15), your mentor/manager completes a performance feedback survey evaluating:

Quality of work delivered
Communication and professionalism
Initiative and problem-solving
Growth and learning throughout the term

What to expect:

Feedback is shared with you
Mentors are encouraged to discuss feedback verbally as part of a wrap-up conversation
The feedback is a key input when assigning final grades

title: Grading
text:
Credit Hours



Enrollment
Hours/Week
Credit Hours




Standard
10 hours
3.0 credits


Extended
Up to 20 hours
6.0 credits

title: Grading
text:
Tips for Success

Send updates on time — missed or late updates impact your grade
Communicate proactively — don’t wait for problems to escalate
Seek feedback early — ask your mentor how you’re doing mid-term
Document your work — keep track of accomplishments for your final review
Be coachable — incorporate feedback and show growth

title: Working with Interns
text:
Your Responsibilities as a Company Partner
This guide helps you get the most out of your APM intern and create a valuable experience for both parties.

title: Working with Interns
text:
Set clear goals, scope, and priorities for the internship
Provide opportunities for regular check-ins (minimum 1x per week recommended)
Act as a mentor by offering guidance, coaching, and feedback
Maintain open, responsive communication
Encourage development of technical and product management skills
Support a final evaluation and wrap-up discussion

title: Working with Interns
text:
Setting Up for Success

Before the Internship Starts

Define 1-3 key projects or focus areas for the intern
Identify who the intern will work with day-to-day
Prepare any necessary accounts, tools, or access
Schedule an onboarding meeting for the first day/week



First Week

Share context about your company, team, and product
Walk through goals and expectations together
Establish communication norms (preferred channels, response times)
Set up recurring 1:1 meetings

title: Working with Interns
text:
Effective Mentorship

Weekly Check-ins

Review progress on current tasks
Discuss blockers and provide support
Give feedback on work quality and approach
Adjust priorities as needed



Feedback Best Practices

Be specific — point to concrete examples
Be timely — don’t wait until the end to share concerns
Balance — acknowledge strengths alongside areas for growth
Be actionable — provide clear guidance on how to improve

title: Working with Interns
section: What to Expect from Your Intern
text:
What to Expect from Your Intern
Interns are expected to:

Confirm expectations and ask clarifying questions
Deliver high-quality work and meet deadlines
Come prepared to meetings with updates and questions
Engage actively and be open to feedback
Proactively communicate progress, blockers, and availability
Send weekly recap emails (every Saturday)

title: Working with Interns
text:
Weekly Progress Emails
Your intern will send you an end-of-week update email every Saturday (CC’ing strategy-program@byu.edu) that includes:

What was accomplished that week
Plans and priorities for the coming week
Any blockers, risks, or dependencies

This keeps everyone aligned and creates a record of progress.

title: Evaluation
text:
End-of-Term Feedback Survey
At the conclusion of the internship, mentors/managers complete a brief performance feedback survey. This feedback is a key input when assigning final grades.
Due Date: April 15, 2026
Survey Link: Complete the Feedback Survey

title: Evaluation
text:
What the Survey Covers
The feedback survey asks you to evaluate your intern on:

Timeliness — Punctuality and meeting deadlines
Communication — Effectiveness in verbal and written communications
High Agency — Taking initiative, solving problems proactively, working independently
Technical Competency — Developing knowledge and skills to complete work effectively
Contribution — Consistently delivering high-quality work output

title: Evaluation
text:
Sharing Feedback

Feedback is shared with the intern
We encourage you to discuss feedback verbally with your intern as part of a wrap-up conversation
This conversation is a valuable learning opportunity for the student

title: Evaluation
text:
Wrap-Up Conversation Tips
Consider discussing:

Highlights — What did they do well? What were you impressed by?
Growth areas — Where could they improve? What skills should they develop?
Career advice — What would help them succeed in product management?
Next steps — Are there opportunities to continue working together?

title: Evaluation
text:
Timeline



Milestone
Date




Internship ends
April 15, 2026


Feedback survey due
April 15, 2026


Grades submitted
April 22, 2026

title: Evaluation
text:
Questions?

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Equipment & Resources
Common questions from company partners about the APM Internship Program.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Do I need to provide the intern with a laptop or equipment?
There is no requirement to provide equipment. Interns may use their own devices (BYOD). However, if you prefer the intern use a company device, you may issue them one.


Do I need to provide a dedicated workspace?
Interns can work remotely or share space. There is no requirement to provide a dedicated desk or office.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
HR & Administrative

Do I need to involve my HR department?
Each company is different. Many companies manage interns directly through the hiring manager or team lead without HR involvement. Others onboard the intern like a regular employee through their typical HR systems and practices. You should determine what is appropriate for your company.


What paperwork is required?
After reviewing the Associate Product Manager Program overview, please email a confirmation of your understanding of these terms to strategy-program@byu.edu


Is there a formal contract or agreement?
The email confirmation serves as acknowledgment of the program terms. If your company requires additional documentation, please contact the program director.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Hours & Compensation

How many hours per week should I expect?

Standard enrollment: 10 hours per week (3.0 credit hours)
Extended enrollment: Up to 20 hours per week (up to 6.0 credit hours)

The intern’s enrollment determines their commitment level.


Can I pay the intern?
Internships are unpaid for the hours associated with academic credit. However, companies may optionally offer compensation for any hours worked beyond the credit-bearing requirement.


Can I extend the internship into summer?
Yes. Companies may choose to offer paid summer extensions following the academic term. Extensions are optional and not required as part of the program.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Working Arrangements

Can the intern work remotely?
Yes. Location is flexible—in-person or remote—depending on your company’s needs and preferences.


What if the intern isn’t meeting expectations?
Communicate concerns early, both to the intern and to the program director. We can help facilitate conversations and provide support. Early intervention usually leads to better outcomes.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Contact
Scott Murff
Program Director, Strategic Management
Brigham Young University
scott.murff@byu.edu

title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Program Overview
STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
The BYU Associate Product Manager (APM) Internships are for-credit, apprenticeship-style internships designed for high-performing undergraduate students majoring in Strategic Management at Brigham Young University.
Students work on real product and product-adjacent initiatives at company partners while earning academic credit toward their degree.

title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Instructor Bio
Scott Murff is an Associate Teaching Professor of Strategy at the BYU Marriott School of Business, where he also serves as program director and teaches courses on business strategy, decision-making, and artificial intelligence. He brings over 15 years of experience at the intersection of business and technology, having worked as a consultant, product manager, and data scientist.
Prior to joining BYU, Scott spent nearly seven years at McKinsey & Company in roles ranging from analytics specialist consultant to principal product manager, where he led product development and performance management initiatives for Fortune 500 clients. His earlier career includes building forecasting models as a VP at Zions Bancorporation and conducting regulatory research at the U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.
Scott holds a Master’s degree in Management Science & Engineering from Stanford University and a B.A. in Economics with a minor in Math, from BYU. He is passionate about helping students apply AI, analytics, and strategy to meaningful real-world problems with both rigor and purpose.

title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Mission and Aims
The mission of Brigham Young University — founded, supported, and guided by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints — is to assist individuals in their quest for perfection and eternal life. That assistance should provide a period of intensive learning in a stimulating setting where a commitment to excellence is expected and the full realization of human potential is pursued.
BYU seeks to develop students of faith, intellect, and character who have the skills and the desire to continue learning and to serve others throughout their lives.
A BYU education should be (1) spiritually strengthening, (2) intellectually enlarging, and (3) character building, leading to (4) lifelong learning and service.
Building on the foundational Mission and Aims, the Marriott School of Business aspires to transform the world through Christlike leadership by developing leaders of faith, intellect, and character guided by the following 4 values:

Faith in Christ - We value deep and abiding faith in Jesus Christ. Our faith gives us the capacity to envision a better future, the confidence to make that future happen, and the courage to act in the face of challenges.
Integrity in Action - We value integrity and hold ourselves to the highest moral and ethical standards. Acting with integrity builds trust, strengthens character, and focuses our ambitions on things of eternal consequence.
Respect for All - We value respect for all individuals as children of God and recognize the inherent worth, divine potential, and agency of each person. A climate of respect and belonging enhances our learning, facilitates collaboration, and encourages personal growth.
Excellence - We value excellence in learning, teaching, research, management, and leadership. An expectation of excellence magnifies our influence and motivates us to continually improve.

We evaluate our decisions and actions by the impact they will have on the academic experience, professional preparation, character development, emotional well-being, and spiritual growth of our students.

title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Getting Help
The following resources are available to get help:

Use Slack or email to contact Professor Murff
Attend office hours

title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Honor Code
In keeping with the principles of the BYU Honor Code, students are expected to be honest in all of their academic work. Academic honesty means, most fundamentally, that any work you present as your own must in fact be your own work and not that of another. Violations of this principle may result in a failing grade in the course and additional disciplinary action by the university. Students are also expected to adhere to the Dress and Grooming Standards. Adherence demonstrates respect for yourself and others and ensures an effective learning and working environment. It is the university’s expectation, and every instructor’s expectation in class, that each student will abide by all Honor Code standards. Please call the Honor Code Office at 422-2847 if you have questions about those standards.

title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Preventing & Responding to Sexual Misconduct
The health and well-being of students is of paramount importance at Brigham Young University. If you or someone you know has experienced sexual harassment (including sexual violence), there are many resources available for assistance.
In accordance with Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, BYU prohibits unlawful sex discrimination, including sexual harassment, against any participant in its education programs or activities. The university also prohibits sexual harassment by its personnel and students. Sexual harassment occurs when
a person is subjected to unwelcome sexual speech or conduct so severe, pervasive, and offensive that it effectively denies their ability to access any BYU education program or activity; any aid, benefit, or service of BYU is conditioned on a person’s participation in unwelcome sexual conduct; or a person suffers sexual assault, dating violence, domestic violence, or stalking on the basis of sex. University policy requires all faculty members to promptly report incidents of sexual harassment that come to their attention in any way, including through face-to-face conversations, a written class assignment or paper, class discussion, email, text, or social media post. Incidents of sexual harassment should be reported to the Title IX Coordinator at t9coordinator@byu.edu or (801) 422-8692 or 1085 WSC. Reports may also be submitted online at https://titleix.byu.edu/report or 1-888-238-1062 (24-hours a day).
BYU offers confidential resources for those affected by sexual harassment, including the university’s Sexual Assault Survivor Advocate, as well as a number of non-confidential resources and services that may be helpful. Additional information about Title IX, the university’s Sexual Harassment Policy, reporting requirements, and resources can be found at http://titleix.byu.edu or by contacting the university’s Title IX Coordinator.

title: STRAT 477R – Associate Product Manager Lab
text:
Student Disability
Brigham Young University is committed to providing a working and learning atmosphere that reasonably accommodates qualified persons with disabilities. A disability is a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities. Whether an impairment is substantially limiting depends on its nature and severity, its duration or expected duration, and its permanent or expected permanent or long-term impact. Examples include vision or hearing impairments, physical disabilities, chronic illnesses, emotional disorders (e.g., depression, anxiety), learning disorders, and attention disorders (e.g., ADHD). If you have a disability which impairs your ability to complete this course successfully, please contact the University Accessibility Center (UAC), 2170 WSC or 801-422-2767 to request a reasonable accommodation. The UAC can also assess students for learning, attention, and emotional concerns. If you feel you have been unlawfully discriminated against on the basis of disability, please contact the Equal Opportunity Office at 801-422-5895, eo_manager@byu.edu, or visit https://hrs.byu.edu/equal-opportunity for help.

After receiving your mentor’s feedback, you will record a 2-5 minute video reflection. This is your opportunity to demonstrate self-awareness, engage thoughtfully with feedback, and show a growth mindset.
Due Date: April 22, 2026
Submission: Upload to YouTube (unlisted) or Loom and submit the link via Learning Suite.
Prompt: Address the following in your video:

Strongest area: Which category (Timeliness, Communication, Agency, Technical Competency, or Contribution) best reflects your strengths this semester? Give an example.
Growth area: Which category needs the most work? What got in the way?
Mentor’s feedback: React to one specific thing your mentor wrote in their comments or suggestions. Do you agree? What will you do with it?
Next time: If you could restart this internship knowing what you know now, what would you do differently?

Keep it conversational—I’m looking for honest self-assessment, not polish.
Rubric:










Criteria
Excellent (10)
Good (7)
Adequate (4)
Weak (0-2)




Self-awareness
Accurately owns strengths and growth areas
Mostly accurate, somewhat surface
Vague or generic
Defensive or no insight


Engages feedback
References specific mentor comments
Acknowledges feedback generally
Mentions feedback in passing
Ignores or dismisses


Growth mindset
Concrete plan for improvement
General intentions
Minimal forward-looking
No reflection on change


Clarity
Organized, right length, professional
Minor issues
Rambling or too brief
Unprepared or inappropriate





Extra Credit (10 points)
Complete the end-of-semester student ratings survey to earn 10 extra credit points.

title: Syllabus
text:
Instructor Bio
Scott Murff is an Associate Teaching Professor of Strategy at the BYU Marriott School of Business, where he also serves as program director and teaches courses on business strategy, decision-making, and artificial intelligence. He brings over 15 years of experience at the intersection of business and technology, having worked as a consultant, product manager, and data scientist.
Prior to joining BYU, Scott spent nearly seven years at McKinsey & Company in roles ranging from analytics specialist consultant to principal product manager, where he led product development and performance management initiatives for Fortune 500 clients. His earlier career includes building forecasting models as a VP at Zions Bancorporation and conducting regulatory research at the U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.
Scott holds a Master’s degree in Management Science & Engineering from Stanford University and a B.A. in Economics with a minor in Math, from BYU. He is passionate about helping students apply AI, analytics, and strategy to meaningful real-world problems with both rigor and purpose.

title: Syllabus
text:
Getting Help
The following resources are available to get help:

Use email or Teams to contact the TAs and Professor Murff
Attend office hours

title: Syllabus
text:
Mission and Aims
The mission of Brigham Young University — founded, supported, and guided by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints — is to assist individuals in their quest for perfection and eternal life. That assistance should provide a period of intensive learning in a stimulating setting where a commitment to excellence is expected and the full realization of human potential is pursued.
BYU seeks to develop students of faith, intellect, and character who have the skills and the desire to continue learning and to serve others throughout their lives.
A BYU education should be (1) spiritually strengthening, (2) intellectually enlarging, and (3) character building, leading to (4) lifelong learning and service.
Building on the foundational Mission and Aims, the Marriott School of Business aspires to transform the world through Christlike leadership by developing leaders of faith, intellect, and character guided by the following 4 values:

Faith in Christ - We value deep and abiding faith in Jesus Christ. Our faith gives us the capacity to envision a better future, the confidence to make that future happen, and the courage to act in the face of challenges.
Integrity in Action - We value integrity and hold ourselves to the highest moral and ethical standards. Acting with integrity builds trust, strengthens character, and focuses our ambitions on things of eternal consequence.
Respect for All - We value respect for all individuals as children of God and recognize the inherent worth, divine potential, and agency of each person. A climate of respect and belonging enhances our learning, facilitates collaboration, and encourages personal growth.
Excellence - We value excellence in learning, teaching, research, management, and leadership. An expectation of excellence magnifies our influence and motivates us to continually improve.

We evaluate our decisions and actions by the impact they will have on the academic experience, professional preparation, character development, emotional well-being, and spiritual growth of our students.

title: Syllabus
text:
Honor Code
In keeping with the principles of the BYU Honor Code, students are expected to be honest in all of their academic work. Academic honesty means, most fundamentally, that any work you present as your own must in fact be your own work and not that of another. Violations of this principle may result in a failing grade in the course and additional disciplinary action by the university. Students are also expected to adhere to the Dress and Grooming Standards. Adherence demonstrates respect for yourself and others and ensures an effective learning and working environment. It is the university’s expectation, and every instructor’s expectation in class, that each student will abide by all Honor Code standards. Please call the Honor Code Office at 422-2847 if you have questions about those standards.

title: Syllabus
text:
Preventing & Responding to Sexual Misconduct
The health and well-being of students is of paramount importance at Brigham Young University. If you or someone you know has experienced sexual harassment (including sexual violence), there are many resources available for assistance.
In accordance with Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, BYU prohibits unlawful sex discrimination, including sexual harassment, against any participant in its education programs or activities. The university also prohibits sexual harassment by its personnel and students. Sexual harassment occurs when
a person is subjected to unwelcome sexual speech or conduct so severe, pervasive, and offensive that it effectively denies their ability to access any BYU education program or activity; any aid, benefit, or service of BYU is conditioned on a person’s participation in unwelcome sexual conduct; or a person suffers sexual assault, dating violence, domestic violence, or stalking on the basis of sex. University policy requires all faculty members to promptly report incidents of sexual harassment that come to their attention in any way, including through face-to-face conversations, a written class assignment or paper, class discussion, email, text, or social media post. Incidents of sexual harassment should be reported to the Title IX Coordinator at t9coordinator@byu.edu or (801) 422-8692 or 1085 WSC. Reports may also be submitted online at https://titleix.byu.edu/report or 1-888-238-1062 (24-hours a day).
BYU offers confidential resources for those affected by sexual harassment, including the university’s Sexual Assault Survivor Advocate, as well as a number of non-confidential resources and services that may be helpful. Additional information about Title IX, the university’s Sexual Harassment Policy, reporting requirements, and resources can be found at http://titleix.byu.edu or by contacting the university’s Title IX Coordinator.

title: Syllabus
text:
Student Disability
Brigham Young University is committed to providing a working and learning atmosphere that reasonably accommodates qualified persons with disabilities. A disability is a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities. Whether an impairment is substantially limiting depends on its nature and severity, its duration or expected duration, and its permanent or expected permanent or long-term impact. Examples include vision or hearing impairments, physical disabilities, chronic illnesses, emotional disorders (e.g., depression, anxiety), learning disorders, and attention disorders (e.g., ADHD). If you have a disability which impairs your ability to complete this course successfully, please contact the University Accessibility Center (UAC), 2170 WSC or 801-422-2767 to request a reasonable accommodation. The UAC can also assess students for learning, attention, and emotional concerns. If you feel you have been unlawfully discriminated against on the basis of disability, please contact the Equal Opportunity Office at 801-422-5895, eo_manager@byu.edu, or visit https://hrs.byu.edu/equal-opportunity for help.

title: Getting Started
text:
Before Your Start Date (Pre-Internship)
Welcome to the BYU Associate Product Manager (APM) Internship Program. This guide will help you hit the ground running.
Companies may begin onboarding early, so you might be contacted before January 7:
Early onboarding is encouraged so you can hit the ground running on January 7.

title: Getting Started
text:
Connect with your assigned mentor/manager
Confirm your work schedule and location (remote or in-person)
Set up any required accounts or access
Review the Program Overview

title: Getting Started
text:
First Week Checklist

Attend onboarding meeting with your mentor
Clarify goals, scope, and priorities for your internship
Understand team communication norms (Slack, email, meetings)
Set up your development environment if applicable
Schedule recurring check-ins (minimum 1x per week recommended)

title: Getting Started
text:
Key Dates



Milestone
Date




Official Start Date
January 7, 2026


End of Internship
April 15, 2026


Weekly Updates Due
Saturday by 11:59 PM

title: Getting Started
text:
Your Responsibilities
As an APM intern, you are expected to:

Confirm expectations and ask clarifying questions as needed
Deliver high-quality work and meet deadlines
Come prepared to meetings with updates, questions, and next steps
Engage actively and be open to feedback
Proactively communicate progress, blockers, and availability
Build competence by learning and applying necessary skills
Send end-of-week recap emails to your manager/mentor with strategy-program@byu.edu in CC

title: Getting Started
text:
What You’ll Be Working On
Students support teams in product management, AI product building, and product-adjacent roles, contributing to:

Product discovery and customer research
Feature definition and prioritization
Prototyping and experimentation
Analytics, insights, and execution support

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Deadline
A key part of your internship is sending a concise end-of-week progress email. This keeps your mentor informed and demonstrates professional communication skills.
Saturday by 11:59 PM
The timing of the end-of-week email is intentional. It gives you time to reflect on accomplishments, set priorities for the coming week, flag any blocker or concerns, and ensures you stay in sync with your manager.

title: Weekly Updates
text:
First weekly email due: January 17, 2026
Final weekly email due: April 18, 2026
Total weekly emails: 14

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Recipients

To: Your assigned mentor/manager
CC: strategy-program@byu.edu

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Email Format
Your weekly update should include three sections:
1. What I Working on and Accomplished This Week [Required] - List completed tasks and deliverables - Be specific about outcomes, not just activities - Include any metrics or results if applicable
2. Plans for Next Week [Required] - Outline your priorities and planned tasks - Be realistic about what you can accomplish
3. Blockers, Risks, or Dependencies [May exclude if none] - Flag anything that might impact your progress - Include items you need from others - Mention any questions or decisions needed

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Example Email
Subject: Weekly Update - [Your Name] - Week of Jan 13

Hi [Mentor Name],

This week I worked on and accomplished the following:
- Completed user interviews with 5 customers
- Drafted initial feature requirements document
- Set up analytics tracking for onboarding flow

Next week, my priorities are:
- Synthesize interview findings into insights report
- Present recommendations to product team
- Begin wireframing priority features

There are a couple things to flag:
- I am still Waiting on access to customer database (requested Tuesday)
- I have a mid-term on Wednesday and will be unvailable that day for any meeting or work time

See you next week,
[Your Name]

title: Weekly Updates
text:
Tips for Effective Updates

Be concise and use bullet points to structure your email
Lead with outcomes — what got done, not just what you worked on
Be honest about blockers — early communication prevents surprises
Send on time — consistency builds trust

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Product Discovery
This page provides foundational resources for the core skills you’ll develop during your APM internship.
Product discovery is the process of understanding customer needs and validating solutions before building.

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Key Activities

Customer interviews
Problem framing
Opportunity assessment
Solution validation



Resources

Continuous Discovery Habits by Teresa Torres
The Mom Test by Rob Fitzpatrick

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Feature Definition & Prioritization
Turning insights into clear, actionable product requirements.

Key Activities

Writing user stories
Defining acceptance criteria
Prioritization frameworks (RICE, MoSCoW, etc.)
Creating product requirements documents (PRDs)



User Story Format
As a [type of user],
I want [goal/desire],
so that [benefit/value].

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Prototyping & Experimentation
Testing ideas quickly before committing to full development.

Key Activities

Low-fidelity wireframes
Clickable prototypes
A/B testing
MVP definition



Tools to Explore

Figma (design & prototyping)
Miro (whiteboarding)
Notion (documentation)

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Analytics & Insights
Using data to inform product decisions.

Key Activities

Defining success metrics
Analyzing user behavior
Creating dashboards
Presenting findings



Common Metrics

Activation rate
Retention/churn
Feature adoption
Task completion rate

title: Product Management Skills
text:
Communication & Stakeholder Management
Product managers spend significant time communicating across teams.

Key Skills

Running effective meetings
Writing clear documentation
Presenting to stakeholders
Managing competing priorities

title: Evaluation
text:
Post-Internship (After April 15)

Complete the feedback survey by April 15
Have a wrap-up conversation with your intern
Optional: Discuss summer extension opportunities if interested

text:

title: Weekly Updates
text:

Each week follows a consistent pattern:







Day
Activity

Throughout Week
